title-group.article-title: Cardiovascular, self-report, and behavioral stress reactivity to the group-based Trier Social Stress Test with pandemic-related protocol adaptations

contrib-group.aff: aDepartment of Psychology, Syracuse University, United States of America
bCollege of Health Science and Technology, Rochester Institute of Technology, United States of America

author-notes.corresp: ⁎Corresponding author at: Department of Psychology, 430 Huntington Hall, Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY 13244, United States of America.

license.license-p: Since January 2020 Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource centre with free information in English and Mandarin on the novel coronavirus COVID-19. The COVID-19 resource centre is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier hereby grants permission to make all its COVID-19-related research that is available on the COVID-19 resource centre - including this research content - immediately available in PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database with rights for unrestricted research re-use and analyses in any form or by any means with acknowledgement of the original source. These permissions are granted for free by Elsevier for as long as the COVID-19 resource centre remains active.

abstract.p: Research using stress induction protocols such as the Trier Social Stress Test (TSST) and the TSST for groups (TSST-G) during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic has been challenging. While institutional review boards have provided guidance on returning to face-to-face research using COVID-19 adaptations (e.g., masking, social distancing), whether these adaptations influence the effectiveness of social-evaluative stress induction remains unknown. We conducted a secondary data analysis from a randomized controlled trial to establish whether using COVID-19 adaptations (i.e., masking, social distancing, and using a single large conference room for the duration of the experiment) to the TSST-G protocol was able to reliably induce stress across cardiovascular, self-report, and behavioral indices of stress. Young adults (N = 53) underwent the TSST-G with COVID-19 adaptations. We measured systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), heart rate (HR), self-reported, and behavioral responses to the TSST-G, and all variables indicated successful stress induction. Increases in SBP (18 mmHg) and DBP (14 mmHg) were similar in magnitude as those in standard in-person TSST protocols. Increases in HR (9 beats per minute) were smaller in magnitude than standard in-person TSST protocols, but slightly larger than increases documented in remote TSST protocols. The cardiovascular, self-report, and behavioral indices of stress reactivity provide confidence in the effectiveness of TSST-G with COVID-19 adaptations to reliably induce stress. In-person TSST protocols with COVID-19 adaptations represent an alternate option to remote TSST protocols for stress induction researchers to use during times when masking or social distancing are necessary.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Certain patterns of stress reactivity (i.e., physiological, cognitive, and behavioral responses to stress; Schlotz, 2013) contribute to numerous adverse health outcomes, including anxiety, depression, and cardiovascular disease (Chida and Steptoe, 2010; Shields and Slavich, 2017; Turner et al., 2020). As such, research has identified stress reactivity as an important intervention target to improve health (Helminen et al., 2021b; Morton et al., 2020). When examining stress reactivity, researchers often use laboratory-based stress induction protocols (Allen et al., 2014). Such protocols allow for a standardized method to induce stress, and can be implemented post-intervention to assess whether interventions are effective at reducing stress reactivity (Morton et al., 2020). The Trier Social Stress Test (TSST; Kirschbaum et al., 1993) represents the current gold standard for stress induction research in which participants perform a speech and serial subtraction task in front of experimenters who maintain neutral facial expressions throughout the task. The TSST and subsequent variations (e.g., the TSST for groups [TSST-G]; von Dawans et al., 2011) are social-evaluative stress tasks which have demonstrated effective activation of stress response systems, including the autonomic nervous system (ANS), hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, self-reported stress appraisals, and observable stress behavior (Allen et al., 2014; Kirschbaum et al., 1993; Thomassin et al., 2018).

The ANS includes some of the most widely measured physiological biomarkers of stress reactivity; namely, cardiovascular indices of reactivity, such as heart rate and blood pressure. During stress activation, the amygdala and hypothalamus work together to activate the sympathetic branch of the ANS. Upon activation of the sympathetic branch of the ANS, the adrenal glands to release epinephrine and norepinephrine (O’Connor et al., 2021). This then contributes to increases in heart rate and blood pressure quickly after the onset of a stressor, such as the TSST. Stretch receptors sense increases in blood pressure and activate a negative feedback loop known as the baroreflex, which then communicates to the brain to reduce blood pressure by decreasing heart rate to keep the body in homeostasis (O’Connor et al., 2021). The increases and decreases in cardiovascular activity can be captured by measuring blood pressure and heart rate before, during, and after the TSST (Allen et al., 2014), which makes the TSST an effective method for investigating stress reactivity and recovery.

The original TSST and TSST-G protocols were developed as in-person laboratory-based tasks. Nevertheless, the ongoing coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has disrupted in-person research, including stress induction studies using the TSST and TSST-G (Pfeifer et al., 2021). Institutional review boards have provided guidance on returning to face-to-face research using COVID-19 adaptations (e.g., masking, social distancing). Yet, whether these adaptations successfully increase physiological (e.g., cardiovascular), self-report, and behavioral indices of stress from baseline to peak stress (i.e., demonstrating effectiveness of stress induction) remains unknown.

sec.title: Stress induction research during the pandemic: limitations of remote protocols
sec.p: National university shutdowns during the beginning of the pandemic included halting all in-person research activities, including stress induction research. During this time, researchers delivered the TSST virtually (DuPont et al., 2022; Eagle et al., 2021; Gunnar et al., 2021; Harvie et al., 2021; Meier et al., 2022). Meta-analyses examining the effectiveness of virtually delivered TSST protocols have demonstrated reliable stress induction across cortisol, heart rate, and self-reported stress (Helminen et al., 2019; Helminen et al., 2021a); however, numerous limitations remain. Despite previous meta-analytic findings suggesting that TSST protocols using immersive virtual environments (e.g., virtual reality) are more effective than screen-based TSST protocols at inducing stress (Helminen et al., 2019), studies implementing virtual versions of the TSST during the pandemic primarily used screen-based protocols (e.g., videoconferencing). One study implementing a screen-based TSST protocol reported the percentage of cortisol responders (i.e., participants whose cortisol increased by at least 1.5 nmol/L) at 64 % (Meier et al., 2022). Previous studies using in-person TSST protocols demonstrated cortisol responder percentages of 73.9 % (Schommer et al., 2003) and 80.5 % (Miller et al., 2013) even when using a more conservative responder cutoff of 2.5 nmol/L. Similarly, two studies using remote TSST protocols found increases in heart rate from 5 to 7 beats per minute (bpm) from baseline to peak (Eagle et al., 2021; Harvie et al., 2021), compared to studies using in-person TSST protocols (15 to 30 bpm; Kirschbaum et al., 1993; Kudielka et al., 2004), though one remote TSST documented a mean increased heart rate by 16 bpm (Meier et al., 2022). One study also assessed participants' perceptions of remote vs. in-person TSST protocols; over half reported that in-person TSST protocols would be either “a little bit worse” or “a lot worse” than remote TSST protocols, indicating that in-person protocols may be more effective for increasing participants' stress appraisals (DuPont et al., 2022). Taken together, this research suggests that remote TSST protocols implemented during the pandemic effectively induce stress; however, the magnitude of stress response may be less than in-person TSST protocols.

Another limitation of remote TSST protocols is that they require participants to collect their own stress measurements with limited assistance, creating some feasibility concerns. Indeed, most remote protocols send physiological data collection devices (e.g., heart rate devices; Eagle et al., 2021) and materials (e.g., saliva collection materials; Gunnar et al., 2021; Meier et al., 2022) to participants via mail or use smartphone-based data collection methods (Harvie et al., 2021). Some remote TSST protocols include hand-delivering physiological measurement devices (e.g., blood pressure equipment) to participants, negating one of the major advantages to remote protocols (i.e., recruiting nationally vs. locally; DuPont et al., 2022). Mailing equipment, using smartphone-based data collection, and hand-delivering physiological measurement devices to participants may create feasibility issues for labs, particularly those using research-grade physiological data collection instruments (e.g., BIOPAC data collection systems; BIOPAC Systems, 2022) which require training to administer and may be too costly for large sample sizes or to replace if not returned. Remote protocols using physiological equipment may also hinder in-person troubleshooting, further impeding feasibility. For example, one remote TSST protocol reported that some participants were unable to print blood pressure recordings using the provided equipment (DuPont et al., 2022).

Remote TSST protocol standardization concerns also exist. For example, one study gathered data on breaches to standardization during remote TSST delivery and documented disruptions, such as presence of roommate or pet and background noise, during 29.2 % participant sessions (DuPont et al., 2022). Remote protocols also limit internal validity of the TSST administration. For instance, participants could complete the TSST in familiar environments (e.g., their bedroom), which reduces novelty of the procedure. Participants could also have access to preferred coping/distraction items (e.g., phone, looking outside; DuPont et al., 2022), which could provide coping resources which reduce the effectiveness of stress induction (Ewert and Chang, 2018; Johnshoy et al., 2020).

Given these feasibility concerns with remote TSST protocols, researchers could instead opt to use in-person protocols with COVID-19 adaptations (masking, social distancing). Such adaptations could facilitate standardization of TSST protocols, for example, by ensuring that trained research assistants (RAs) administer and troubleshoot physiological data collection and that all participants complete the TSST in the same environment and without distractions. However, whether TSST protocols using such COVID-19 adaptations reliably induce stress remains unknown (Pfeifer et al., 2021).

Remote TSST protocols used during the pandemic have also been limited to the single-person TSST format, which requires more time and resources to acquire adequate sample sizes relative to group-based TSST protocols, such as TSST-G. The TSST-G, compared to the original TSST, can gather data with up to six participants per experimental session rather than one participant at a time (von Dawans et al., 2011). Given the resource-intensiveness of the original TSST protocol (e.g., at least three experimenters per session), collecting data with several participants simultaneously provides clear feasibility advantages for timely data collection. However, no studies (remote or in-person) have demonstrated effectiveness of administering the TSST-G during the pandemic.

sec.title: Pandemic-related adaptations for in-person TSST protocols
sec.p: Widespread masking, sterilizing, and social distancing represent prominent public health recommendations to reduce COVID-19 transmission and acquisition. Despite recent calls for research to establish effectiveness of COVID-19 adaptations to in-person stress induction protocols (Pfeifer et al., 2021), no studies have examined effectiveness of stress induction TSST-G protocols using these pandemic-related adaptions. In particular, it is important to know whether masking affects stress induction protocols which rely on social-evaluative threat (i.e., knowing that one is being judged by others; Dickerson and Kemeny, 2004), as masking might make it difficult to see experimenters' neutral facial expressions. Such findings could also inform needed adaptations to delivering TSST-G protocols during infectious disease outbreaks in general. Previous research has indicated that participants more accurately recognize neutral facial expressions when experimenters' mouths are visible (Guarnera et al., 2015). Using masks with clear inserts (Safe “N” Clear, 2022) in which some of the mouth region is visible would plausibly confer similar levels of social-evaluative threat as not masking. However, whether using these types of masks (or any masks) influences the effectiveness of TSST protocols remains unknown.

Beyond masking, there are logistical adaptations related to sterilizing materials and social distancing to consider for in-person TSST protocols administered during a pandemic. For instance, standard TSST protocols typically use at least two rooms—one for baseline procedures (e.g., setting up physiological recording equipment with participants) and post-TSST procedures (e.g., removing equipment, debriefing participants), and one for speech and math tasks. Separate rooms are recommended to increase the novelty and uncontrollability of the procedure (Birkett, 2011), both of which increase the effectiveness of a stressor (Kudielka et al., 2007). Thus, cleaning and sterilizing at least two spaces requires additional time and money, potentially impacting feasibility. Further, these rooms might not be large enough to accommodate social distancing requirements, particularly if the TSST is conducted in a group format. During a pandemic, using a single large room (e.g., conference room) throughout the experiment could reduce post-experiment cleaning requirements and facilitate adherence to social distancing guidelines. However, given that prior research recommends two rooms for effective stress induction (Birkett, 2011), establishing whether conducting a TSST study in a single large room still effectively induces stress is necessary to be able to recommend this as a COVID-19 adaptation for future research.

sec.title: The present study
sec.p: The purpose of this study is to establish whether a group-based TSST with COVID-19 adaptations can effectively induce stress measured via increases in baseline-to-peak measures of cardiovascular, self-reported, behavioral indices of stress. We aim to accomplish this with a secondary data analysis using data collected from a randomized controlled trial (RCT) which examined the effects of brief interventions (i.e., a 40-min compassion training or a 40-min cognitive reappraisal training) prior to stress induction. The RCT was conducted during Spring and Summer 2022, and this study implemented the TSST-G with several COVID-19 adaptations, including masking, social distancing, and using a single large conference room.

sec.title: Power analysis
sec.p: We conducted a power analysis using GLMMPSE 3.0.0 (Kreidler et al., 2013) to identify the necessary sample size to test the main effect of time on stress reactivity. Inputs included two time points, baseline and peak stress (i.e., the maximum heart rate and blood pressure reading during the TSST). Estimated heart rate and blood pressure were entered for both time points based on a previous TSST study in a similar population of young adults (Rodeback et al., 2020). To achieve a power of 0.80 with a Type I error rate of 0.05, the minimum required sample size was 26, indicating this study was sufficiently powered.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Inclusion criteria were young adults aged ≥18 and enrolled in an undergraduate psychology course. Exclusion criteria were included a history of a heart condition and past-six-month hospitalization. Participants were excluded if they selected “Yes” to the question “Do you have a heart condition?” and/or the question “Have you been hospitalized for mental health support in the last 6 months?” Participants were also excluded if they exhibited a resting baseline SBP of ≥140 mmHg, a resting DBP of ≥90 mmHg, or a resting HR of ≥100. Young adults (n = 59) aged 18 to 22 years old consented to participate in this study for course credit in an introductory psychology course. Three participants did not attend the laboratory session of the experiment, one participant self-reported a heart condition, and two participants had resting heart rates of >100 beats per minute, indicating tachycardia (Gopinathannair and Olshansky, 2015), resulting in an analytic sample of 53 participants.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: All study procedures were approved by Syracuse University's institutional review board. Procedures consisted of a virtual meeting to complete baseline measures and a single in-person lab session where participants completed a pre-TSST-G intervention and underwent the TSST-G within two weeks of the virtual meeting.

During the 15- to 30-minute virtual meeting, participants met with a graduate student RA who explained the study, consented participants to the study, and administered an online assessment (e.g., demographic questions, inclusion criteria). The RA then confirmed participants' in-person appointment and reminded participants to avoid wearing bulky clothing (e.g., sweatshirts) to the in-person session as they would need to wear a blood pressure cuff around their upper arm.

The in-person portion of the experiment was a 2- to 2.5-hour session scheduled with two to five participants at a time. The entire in-person session was completed in one large conference room that allowed for social distancing and was outfitted with an air purifier. Upon arrival, trained RAs provided participants with FDA-approved masks with a clear insert that made it possible to see participants' mouths (Safe “N” Clear, 2022) and secured a blood pressure cuff on participants' non-dominant arms. Cuffs were connected to a ocillometric blood pressure devices, which have demonstrated sensitivity to stress induction tasks (DuPont et al., 2022; Gecaite et al., 2019). Each device was placed in a carrier pouch with a harness. Each harness included a participant identification number. RAs then asked participants to place the harness over their shoulders and allow the devices to rest in their laps for the duration of the experiment. Participants then completed time-sensitive baseline self-report data that was unable to be collected at the virtual meeting (e.g., baseline state stress). Participants then read neutral content magazines (e.g., home decorating) until 25 min elapsed from the time they arrived and sat down in their assigned chair to ensure blood pressure and heart rate stabilized (Mahe et al., 2017). Three baseline blood pressure and heart rate measurements were then taken, spaced apart by one minute (Whelton et al., 2018). Next, participants completed a 40-minute intervention, which consisted of either (1) a brief compassion-based intervention using materials and practices adapted from previous research (Cattani et al., 2021; Weng et al., 2013) or (2) a time- and attention-matched cognitive reappraisal training control group adapted from previous research (Weng et al., 2013). Cardiovascular and self-report measurements were completed immediately following the intervention.

After post-intervention measurements were collected, the interventionist left the room and RAs placed dividers between participants to prevent interaction between participants and mitigate the potential for visual social support during the TSST-G administration (von Dawans et al., 2011). Participants were able to hear each other during the speech and math tasks. RAs also set up a prop video camera, along with a table and chairs for the TSST-G panel. A different set of trained RAs who had not interacted with participants previously then entered the room as the TSST-G panelists. RAs wore white lab coats and the same masks with clear inserts to allow participants to see their mouths throughout the stress task. Panelists sat across the table from participants and were able to see all participants. Participants were able to see the TSST-G panelists, but the dividers prevented them from seeing each other.

The lead TSST-G panelist asked participants to prepare a speech in which they would be introducing themselves to a new classroom, and allowed participants three minutes to prepare (von Dawans et al., 2011). This prompt was selected as it may be more developmentally applicable for younger populations compared to other prompts (e.g., mock job interview; Yim et al., 2015). Blood pressure and heart rate measurements were taken immediately after the speech preparation. Participants were then called on using the participant identification numbers attached to each blood pressure device. Participants were selected in seemingly random order (i.e., they were not called on starting at participant 1 and counting up) to speak for two minutes each (von Dawans et al., 2011). While the order may have seemed random to participants, it was standardized to be the same across administrations. After participants completed the speech task, they were each asked in seemingly random order to subtract a two-digit number from a four-digit number for 80 s each for the math portion of the TSST-G. Blood pressure and heart rate measurements were taken four times throughout the speech and math tasks (i.e., once in the middle and once at the end of each task). Of these four measurements, the maximum measurement was taken to be participants' peak stress measurement.

Upon completing the TSST-G, another state stress measure was administered with the dividers, video camera, and TSST-G panelists still in the room. After these measurements, TSST-G panelists left the room, and RAs removed all props and dividers. Participants were given magazines to read throughout the rest of the in-person session. Cardiovascular and self-report recovery measurements were administered twice during this period (i.e., 10 min post-TSST-G, and 20 min post-TSST-G). After the second recovery measurement, blood pressure cuffs were removed, and participants were debriefed and were given time to ask questions related to the experiment. Since the purpose of this study was to establish reliable stress reactivity using COVID adaptations, the post-TSST-G measurements were not included in this study's data analysis.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Demographic data and inclusion and exclusion criteria were collected at the initial virtual meeting. Cardiovascular measurements were taken during the in-person session at baseline, post-intervention, and several times throughout the TSST-G. Self-reported state stress was assessed at baseline, post-intervention, and post-TSST-G. To establish reliable stress induction using the TSST-G with COVID-19 adaptations, we used the baseline and peak measurements for the cardiovascular and self-reported stress reactivity analyses.

sec.title: Cardiovascular stress reactivity
sec.p: Cardiovascular stress reactivity was measured via systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), and heart rate using the SunTech Medical Oscar 2 Ambulatory Blood Pressure Monitor, an Orbit Ambulatory Blood Pressure Monitor Cuff. This ocillometric blood pressure measuring system has been clinically validated (Goodwin et al., 2007; Jones et al., 2004) and used in prior stress induction research (Gecaite et al., 2019).

sec.title: Self-reported stress reactivity
sec.p: Self-report state stress reactivity was assessed with the six-item State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-6; Marteau and Bekker, 1992), which asks how much participants agree with statements of feelings of stress in the current moment. The STAI-6 is often used to measure self-reported stress reactivity in response to acute stress induction (Morton et al., 2020). Items are summed to create a total score with higher scores indicating higher state stress (Cronbach's α across time points = 0.84–0.87).

sec.title: Self-reported appraisal of overall TSST-G stressfulness
sec.p: Participants were asked to rate their perception of the stressfulness of the TSST-G with a single question, “Did you find the interview/math portion of the experiment to be stressful?” They were given four response options, coded as 1 (Not at all), 2 (Somewhat), 3 (Moderately so), and 4 (Very much so).

sec.title: Ratings of observed stress behavior
sec.p: After each stress task, the lead TSST-G panelist (i.e., the panelist who read the script during the TSST-G) completed a rating of observable stress across participants, by answering the question, “As a group, how stressed did participants appear to be during the TSST-G?” Panelists rated participants' stress on a scale from 1 to 7, with anchors at 1 (not at all stressed), 4 (moderately stressed), and 7 (extremely stressed). Based on previous research using behavioral coding to assess stress behavior (Santos et al., 2021; Thomassin et al., 2018), panelists were provided examples of stressed behavior (e.g., looking away, fidgeting, stammering) and non-stressed behavior (e.g., eye contact, steady speech, upright posture) from which to base their ratings.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: All data analyses were conducted in SPSS, version 27. Descriptive statistics were conducted to describe sample demographics and cardiovascular and self-reported stress. Some participants were missing data for the speech preparation (n = 7 missing), first recovery (n = 4), second recovery (n = 3) time points. For the main analyses, we conducted four paired-samples t-tests across outcome variables (SBP, DBP, heart rate, and state stress) to assess whether the TSST-G successfully induced stress (von Dawans et al., 2011). We then completed exploratory analyses using paired-samples t-tests with pairwise deletion of missing data to compare baseline to the speech preparation period (i.e., anticipatory stress) and recovery time points to understand whether cardiovascular and self-reported stress significantly increased during anticipatory and peak stress and returned to resting levels during recovery periods.

Next, we calculated the mean TSST-G stressfulness rating across all participants as another measure of self-reported stress to identify whether participants appraised the overall TSST-G to be “not at all,” “somewhat,” “moderately,” or “very” stressful. We also evaluated the proportion of participants who rated the TSST-G as “somewhat,” “moderately,” or “very” stressful compared to the proportion of participants who reported that it was “not at all” stressful. Finally, we calculated the mean observed behavioral stress rating given to each group of participants by the TSST lead panelist.

sec.title: Participant characteristics
sec.p:
Participants included cisgender women (n = 24; 45.3 %) and cisgender men (n = 29; 54.7 %), reported a mean age of 19.1 (SD = 1.0), and reported their race/ethnicity as White (n = 21; 39.6 %), Asian (n = 12; 22.6 %), Black/African American (n = 9; 17.0 %), multiracial (n = 6; 11.3 %), Latinx (n = 4; 7.5 %), and Middle Eastern (n = 1; 1.9 %). Additional sample demographics, including sexual identity and household income, are included in Table 1 .Table 1

sec.title: Cardiovascular stress reactivity
sec.p:
Table 2 displays the descriptive statistics of cardiovascular reactivity variables across each time point. Paired samples t-tests assessing stress reactivity from baseline to peak stress indicated SBP (t(52) = 12.5; p < .001; Cohen's d = 1.72), DBP (t(52) = 11.48; p < .001; Cohen's d = 1.58), and heart rate (t(52) = 5.64; p < .001; Cohen's d = 0.77) all significantly increased from baseline to peak stress,.Table 2
Descriptive statistics for cardiovascular, self-reported, and behavioral indices of stress.Table 2

Valid N (physiological)5346534950
Systolic BP (mmHg)115.6 (10.9)122.7 (11.2)133.3 (10.9)119.6 (15.2)116.1 (14.0)
Diastolic BP (mmHg)67.9 (6.9)74.7 (9.5)82.0 (8.6)71.4 (9.6)70.8 (11.1)
Heart Rate (bpm)77.4 (9.7)76.8 (11.6)86.4 (12.4)75.8 (10.6)75.2 (9.4)
Valid N (self-report)53–535252
Self-reported state stress (STAI-6)36.2 (12.4)–43.8 (13.9)32.6 (10.8)31.1 (10.2)
Perception of TSST-G stressfulness––2.75 (1.03)––
Ratings of observed stress behavior––5.36 (1.32)––
Note. M = mean; SD = standard deviation; BP = blood pressure; mmHg = millimeters of mercury; bpm = beats per minute; STAI-6 = 6-item State Trait Anxiety Inventory; TSST-G = Trier Social Stress Test for Groups. The mean value for perceptions of TSST-G stressfulness correspond to somewhat to moderately stressful (observed range = 1–4; 1 = not at all; 2 = somewhat; 3 = moderately; 4 = very much). The mean value for ratings of observed stress behavior correspond to moderately to extremely stressed (observed range = 4–7; 1 = not at all; 4 = moderately; 7 = extremely).

Exploratory analyses revealed SBP significantly increased from baseline to the speech preparation period, t(45) = 5.32; p < .001; Cohen's d = 0.79. Baseline SBP was significantly lower than SBP during the first recovery period, t(48) = 2.29; p = .03; Cohen's d = 0.33, but baseline SBP did not significantly differ from SBP during the second recovery period, t(49) = 0.67; p = .50; Cohen's d = 0.10.

DBP also significantly increased from baseline to the speech preparation, t(45) = 6.21; p < .001; Cohen's d = 0.92. Baseline DBP was significantly lower than DBP during the first recovery period, t(48) = 2.78; p = .008; Cohen's d = 0.40, and baseline DBP was still slightly lower than DBP during the second recovery period, t(49) = 2.30; p = .26; Cohen's d = 0.33.

Finally, HR did not significantly increase from baseline to the speech preparation, t(45) = −0.24; p = .81; Cohen's d = −0.04. Baseline HR did not significantly differ from HR during the first recovery period, t(48) = −1.64; p = .11; Cohen's d = −0.23, and baseline HR was slightly higher than HR during the second recovery period, t(49) = −2.19; p = .03; Cohen's d = −0.31.

sec.title: Self-reported stress reactivity
sec.p: Table 2 displays the descriptive statistics of self-reported state stress across each time point. Paired samples t-tests revealed self-reported state stress significantly increased from baseline to post-TSST-G, t(52) = 3.95; p < .001; Cohen's d = 0.54. Baseline self-reported state stress was significantly higher than state stress during the first recovery period, t(51) = −2.35; p = .02; Cohen's d = −0.33, and the second recovery period, t(51) = −3.25; p = .002; Cohen's d = −0.45.

sec.title: Self-reported appraisal of overall TSST-G stressfulness
sec.p: Overall, participants rated the stressfulness of the TSST-G as a 2.75 (SD = 1.03). Only 8 participants (15 %) indicated that they did not find the TSST-G to be stressful at all, while 11 (21 %) indicated it was somewhat stressful, 19 (36 %) indicated it was moderately stressful, and 14 (26 %) indicated it was very stressful.

sec.title: Ratings of observed stress behaviors
sec.p: TSST-G panelists, on average, rated the observed stress of participants as 5.36 (SD = 1.32) out of a possible range of 1 to 7.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Responding to calls for research needing to determine whether COVID-19-adapted TSST protocols can effectively induce stress (Pfeifer et al., 2021), this study implemented several COVID-19 adaptations to the TSST-G protocol and examined whether the adapted protocol increased stress across cardiovascular, self-report, and behavioral indices. Specific adaptations included (1) using masks with clear inserts, (2) social distancing, and (3) using one large conference room for the duration of the experiment instead of two separate rooms. This study's COVID-19-adapted TSST-G protocol effectively induced stress across cardiovascular (i.e., SBP, DBP, HR), self-report, and behavioral indices of stress. Notably, increases in SBP (18 mmHg) and DBP (14 mmHg) were similar in magnitude to standard in-person TSST protocols (Kupper et al., 2021). Increases in HR in this study were smaller (9 bpm) than standard in-person TSST protocols (Kirschbaum et al., 1993; Kudielka et al., 2004), though still significant. Significant self-report and behavioral ratings of stress provided additional confidence in the effectiveness of the protocol.

Because this study took place during the COVID-19 pandemic, it is important to note that this period of widespread illness and social isolation significantly affected young adults' lives (Huckins et al., 2020; Son et al., 2020). During the pandemic, college students reported more stress, depression, anxiety, health-related fears, difficulty concentrating, and disruptions to sleep (Huckins et al., 2020; Son et al., 2020). Because of this unprecedented disruption to everyday life, it is possible that participants' stress reactivity during the pandemic was also affected (e.g., increased social anxiety, increased health-related anxiety from participating in an in-person study). Thus, results from this study may be affected by the time period in which it was conducted and may not be directly comparable to pre-pandemic stress reactivity studies.

Previous stress induction research during the COVID-19 pandemic used remote TSST protocols administered over videoconference (DuPont et al., 2022; Eagle et al., 2021; Gunnar et al., 2021; Harvie et al., 2021; Meier et al., 2022). While studies using remote TSST protocols have demonstrated reliable stress induction, remote administration presents with several challenges, such as needing to mail physiological measurement devices to participants, lacking standardization across study environments, and lacking the ability to troubleshoot if equipment stops working. The adapted protocol tested in this study provides an alternative to using remote TSST protocols for feasibly and reliably conducting stress induction studies during the COVID-19 pandemic and future instances when masking and social distancing may be necessary.

While results reinforced the effectiveness of the TSST-G protocol with COVID-19 adaptations, the change in HR in response to the stress test was smaller than expected. These unexpected results may be due to several reasons. First, HR in this study was measured only four times during the speech and math tasks of the TSST-G, whereas other studies have implemented continuous HR monitoring (von Dawans et al., 2011). Our HR measurement was derived from blood pressure machines, which do not have a continuous HR monitoring option. Thus, it is possible that we missed the peak HR measurement, artificially decreasing the baseline to peak change in HR. Second, this study was a secondary analysis of an RCT in which participants underwent one of two possible interventions prior to the TSST-G. Participating in an intervention may have influenced HR during the TSST-G providing a coping strategy which reduced HR reactivity. Nevertheless, HR increases in this study were larger than those reported in remote TSST protocols (Eagle et al., 2021; Harvie et al., 2021).

Beyond providing a protocol for researchers to use during a pandemic, this study also provides non-pandemic-related benefits for future stress induction research. To our knowledge, this is the first study that described a protocol which effectively induced stress using a single, large conference room for the duration of the study rather than two separate rooms by bringing TSST-G materials (e.g., video camera, participant dividers) into the room for the duration of the stress test. This provides an option for researchers with limited space to conduct TSST studies in a conference room.

sec.title: Limitations and future directions
sec.p: Though researchers may now conduct in-person TSST protocols using COVID-19 adaptations with increased confidence, this study includes several limitations that future research should address. Our study only used ANS measures to assess physiological reactivity. Thus, it is unknown whether these results may extend to HPA axis biomarkers (e.g., cortisol). Future research should examine whether cortisol and other HPA axis measures reliably increase in response to the TSST and TSST-G with COVID-19 adaptations. This would provide more confidence in using pandemic-adapted stress induction protocols in any potential future times of masking and social distancing. Including HPA axis measures would also increase confidence in the ability to effectively induce stress using a single room for stress induction experiments. Further, future studies using masking and social distancing and measuring cortisol could compare whether this pandemic-adapted protocol produces a similar ratio of cortisol responders (i.e., participant's who exhibit at least 1.5 nmol/L increase in cortisol in response to stress) to non-responders as standard protocols (Miller et al., 2013). Another limitation was that we also used a single-item rating scale which was completed by the TSST-G panel lead based on observable behavior during the TSST-G. Future studies may benefit from coding for behavior throughout the TSST-G (Santos et al., 2021; Thomassin et al., 2018), which would provide a more robust (but more resource-intensive) measure of behavioral stress.

This study also had limitations related to study and participant characteristics. First, this this study was a secondary data analysis from an RCT. As noted previously, it is possible that participation in a brief intervention may have affected heart rate reactivity. The interventions implemented prior to the TSST-G could have also attenuated all stress variables, and it is possible that SBP, DBP, HR, and self-reported stress may all have been higher if there were no interventions implemented prior to stress induction. Intervention effects from this study will be reported elsewhere, but briefly, results demonstrated participants in the compassion intervention exhibited lower DBP reactivity than the control intervention (Helminen, 2023). Thus, the DBP reactivity for the overall sample reported in this study may be an underestimate, given that it is likely the compassion intervention attenuated DBP reactivity for approximately half of the sample.

Further, the interventions may have also facilitated better recovery from stress, which may be why participants in this study self-reported lower state stress during the recovery periods than during the baseline. A future study implementing a TSST protocol with the COVID-19 adaptations without an intervention component may provide more confidence in the stress induction abilities of the adapted protocol. Further, although participants in this study were relatively balanced across cisgender women and men and relatively diverse in terms of racial/ethnic identity, all participants were young adult college students, limiting the generalizability of these results to younger or older populations. Given demonstrated age differences in stress reactivity (Allen et al., 2017; Kudielka et al., 2004), future studies may benefit from assessing whether COVID-19 adapted TSST protocols are effective for younger and older populations.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not for profit sectors.

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
